title: How to Reuse Dryer Lint

steps.headline: Collect dryer lint in an empty coffee container or plastic bin.
steps.description: Every time you clean out the lint screen from your dryer, put it in a closed container nearby. An empty coffee can or a plastic container with a lid work fine for storing your lint. Keep the container away from any heat sources or open flames since the lint is extremely flammable.

steps.headline: Clean up spills with dryer lint in place of paper towels.
steps.description: Gather a handful of dryer lint and set it on top of your next spill so it soaks up the liquid. If the dryer lint doesn’t sop up the spill on its own, then rub it back and forth until it absorbs all the liquid. Throw out the dryer lint after you use it. Don’t reuse dryer lint that you used to pick up spills since you could easily spread around germs and bacteria.

steps.headline: Use dryer lint as an easy fire starter.
steps.description: Build a fire using logs or sticks in a fire pit, and tuck large wads of dryer lint underneath them. You may also stuff used toilet paper tubes with lint so it doesn’t blow away in windy conditions. Use a utility lighter with a long barrel to set the dry lint on fire. The lint will catch quickly and keep your fire burning for awhile! Mix melted wax and dryer lint in a cardboard egg carton if you want to make a fire starter that takes longer to burn. Light the egg carton to help bigger logs catch on fire.Warning: Dryer lint is extremely flammable. Make sure it’s only near an open flame or heat source if you plan on lighting it on fire.

steps.headline: Put lint in a compost bin to use in a garden.
steps.description: Spread the dryer lint evenly across the surface of your compost bin and wet it with a hose or watering can. The fibers from the lint will break down over time. Once your compost is ready, spread it across your soil to add nutrients to it. Don’t compost lint if you used dryer sheets for your laundry since they contain perfumes and chemicals.

steps.headline: Use the lint as mulch on your outdoor plants.
steps.description: Rip your dryer lint into small pieces and spread it over the soil around your plants. Water the lint so it doesn’t blow away and it absorbs into the soil. Apply the lint during the winter months so your plants stay warm and retain water. Do not use dryer lint in your yard if you used scented detergents or dryer sheets, since these contain chemicals and perfumes that could harm your plants.

steps.headline: Pack boxes or gifts with dryer lint to protect what’s inside.
steps.description: Instead of spending money on styrofoam or tissue paper, collect your dryer lint and fill the container you’re using. Make sure there’s enough lint to fill the package tightly so it doesn’t move around or break when it’s being transported. If you don’t have enough dryer lint to fill the package, then use newspapers or other soft recyclables to fill in any gaps.

steps.headline: Let pet rodents use the lint as bedding.
steps.description: Many pets, such as guinea pigs, rats, and mice, need comfortable bedding to make their nests. Put some of your dryer lint into their cage and let them use it how they want. You can add as much or as little lint to your pet’s cage as you want. Don’t use dryer lint if you have a cage heater since the lint could create a fire hazard. Make sure the lint doesn’t have scented laundry products in it since the chemicals and perfumes could cause skin irritation on your pets.

steps.headline: Fill a pillow or stuffed animal with lint to make it soft and plushy.
steps.description: Sew or glue fabric together in the pattern you want to make, but leave at least 1 side undone so you can stuff it. Pack the dryer lint you have into the fabric and stuff it as much or as little as you want. The stuffed animal or pillow will be larger and fluffier when you use more lint. When you’re finished, seal the final seam and it’s ready to use. Don’t keep any pillows or stuffed animals near fire hazards since dryer lint will ignite quickly.

steps.headline: Combine lint, flour, and water to create homemade modeling clay.
steps.description: Tear your dryer lint into small pieces until you have 3 cups. Pour in 1 cup (120 g) of flour and 2 cups (470 ml) of water and set your stove to low heat. Continually stir the mixture until it’s smooth and binds to itself. Pour the mix onto a baking tray with wax paper and let it cool completely before using it. Once it’s cool, shape and model the clay into anything you want. When you’re finished playing, store the clay in an airtight container. The clay will harden after 3-7 days. Let your sculpture dry completely if you want to paint and decorate it.

steps.headline: Substitute dryer lint in your paper mache.
steps.description: Combine 2 cups (470 ml) of water, ⅔ cup (80 g) of flour, and 3 cups of dryer lint in a large saucepan over medium heat. Stir the mixture constantly and remove it from the heat once it starts forming peaks. Pour the mixture onto a flat baking sheet covered with wax paper so it can cool. When you’re ready, spread the lint paste onto the mold you’re using and let it air-dry completely for about 1 week. The lint paste will keep for about 3 days in an airtight container before it starts to harden.Tip: Try using differently shaped molds, such as bowls, bottles, or a balloon, to make unique containers.

steps.headline: Make your own paper using dryer lint.
steps.description: Soak the lint in warm water for about 30 minutes so it breaks down easier while making your paper. Put 1 cup of lint in a blender, fill it to the top with water, and blend it until it’s smooth. Pour the lint mixture into a screened frame and spread the lint around evenly. Press any excess water out and let your paper dry for about 6 hours in the frame. Use your homemade paper in scrapbooks or for fun decorations. Add food coloring or paint to the lint mixture to make colored paper.
